metadata.title: If men could learn from history, what lessons it might teach us!’ Samuel Taylor Coleridge
affiliations: Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of Faculty of Public Health. All rights reserved. For permissions, please e-mail: journals.permissions@oup.com
metadata.abstract: UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed calls 2020, ‘the year we must change course’. How can Public Health contribute to changing the course? The Chile/Madrid Climate Change Conference ended with mixed results, raising questions about tools for collectively addressing global challenges. Of course, Public Health can contribute through developing and strengthening the evidence base and assessing the effectiveness of policies. However, Public Health has another important role to play if it is to contribute to ‘changing the course’. Jarman et al 17 in their online article ‘Brexit is just a symptom: the constitutional weaknesses it reveals have serious consequences for health’ state ‘weak accountability, executive dominance and lack of transparency all have profound implications for health policy’ and are of the opinion that ‘few of the political mechanisms adopted in recent years that could have constrained executive dominance have proven to be effective’. To change course the role of public health should include critically examining not just the tools and processes but also the systems and institutions that have the power to influence and manipulate the opportunities and challenges to reach the crucial global goals.

introduction: Global advocacy groups have named 2020 a ‘super year’ for activism and action. They advocate activism and action to reach the people furthest behind and rebalancing the relationship between people and nature through supporting both local initiatives and innovation. Virginia Berridge’s 2007 BMJ article ‘Public health activism: lessons from history?’16 outlines how knowledge about public health campaigns from the past can help current health campaigners to draw up effective strategies. She argues that networks of health organizations and pressure groups are vital as they have ‘first established the area of concern at the national (and sometimes local) level and then developed it internationally’. Berridge’s article is as relevant today as it was over a decade ago. She states ‘activism has a dual and interconnected rationale—pushing for policy change but also helping to achieve cultural change’.

UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed calls 2020, ‘the year we must change course’. How can Public Health contribute to changing the course? The Chile/Madrid Climate Change Conference ended with mixed results, raising questions about tools for collectively addressing global challenges. Of course, Public Health can contribute through developing and strengthening the evidence base and assessing the effectiveness of policies. However, Public Health has another important role to play if it is to contribute to ‘changing the course’. Jarman et al 17 in their online article ‘Brexit is just a symptom: the constitutional weaknesses it reveals have serious consequences for health’ state ‘weak accountability, executive dominance and lack of transparency all have profound implications for health policy’ and are of the opinion that ‘few of the political mechanisms adopted in recent years that could have constrained executive dominance have proven to be effective’. To change course the role of public health should include critically examining not just the tools and processes but also the systems and institutions that have the power to influence and manipulate the opportunities and challenges to reach the crucial global goals.

References: Henry N. Coleridge Table Talk (1821–1834) Specimens of the Table Talk of S.T. Coleridge, 1835.

summary: Global advocacy groups have named 2020 a ‘super year’ for activism and action. They advocate activism and action to reach the people furthest behind and rebalancing the relationship between people and nature through supporting both local initiatives and innovation.

Parallels are already being drawn between this new decade and the 1920s, the so-called Roaring Twenties, a period of economic prosperity with a distinctive cultural edge in the United States and Europe.
Technology with the proliferation of cars, telephones, movies, radio and electrical appliances and accelerated consumer demand.
It is said to be the dawn of celebrity culture when sports heroes and movie stars were venerated.
The end of the era was marked by the Wall Street Crash of 1929.
The British historian, Lucy Moore noted that systemic weaknesses underlay the effervescence of the era masking the underlying poverty and inequalities.
In her book ‘Anything Goes: A Biography of the Roaring Twenties’18 she wrote: ‘the crash did not cause the Depression: that was part of a far broader malaise.

What it did was expose the weaknesses that underpinned the confidence and optimism of the 1920s— poor distribution of income, a weak banking structure and insufficient regulations, the economy’s dependence on new consumer goods, the overextension of industry and the Government’s blind belief that promoting business interests would make America uniformly prosperous.’
In this ‘super year’ of activism and action Public Health should keep Moore’s analysis in mind and learn lessons from the past to ensure Public Health’s activism and actions are effective.

Introduction: Global advocacy groups have named 2020 a ‘super year’ for activism and action. They advocate activism and action to reach the people furthest behind and rebalancing the relationship between people and nature through supporting both local initiatives and innovation.

Parallels are already being drawn between this new decade and the 1920s, the so-called Roaring Twenties, a period of economic prosperity with a distinctive cultural edge in the United States and Europe.
Results: Technology with the proliferation of cars, telephones, movies, radio and electrical appliances and accelerated consumer demand.
It is said to be the dawn of celebrity culture when sports heroes and movie stars were venerated.
The end of the era was marked by the Wall Street Crash of 1929.
The British historian, Lucy Moore noted that systemic weaknesses underlay the effervescence of the era masking the underlying poverty and inequalities.
In her book ‘Anything Goes: A Biography of the Roaring Twenties’18 she wrote: ‘the crash did not cause the Depression: that was part of a far broader malaise.
Conclusion: What it did was expose the weaknesses that underpinned the confidence and optimism of the 1920s— poor distribution of income, a weak banking structure and insufficient regulations, the economy’s dependence on new consumer goods, the overextension of industry and the Government’s blind belief that promoting business interests would make America uniformly prosperous.’
In this ‘super year’ of activism and action Public Health should keep Moore’s analysis in mind and learn lessons from the past to ensure Public Health’s activism and actions are effective.
